Q: Unable to add packages to uv project in Ubuntu A:

I think it has to do with how you installed uv in ubuntu:

Did you do a pip install uv?

You have to install on the top level as shown here:

curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
# or:
wget -qO- https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

You do it as normal user and not as root.

After:

uv init new_app

you have to enter the project folder first:

cd new_app

Only then when you do

uv add --link-mode copy flask requests

uv will target the new_app/.venv folder. The other thing is - why you need --link-mode at all? uv anyway uses softlinks. It installs everything centrally and uses softlinks in the projects (memory-saving). So just do:

uv add copy flask requests

astral says in https://docs.astral.sh/uv/reference/settings/ :

WARNING: The use of symlink link mode is discouraged, as they create tight coupling between the cache and the target environment. For example, clearing the cache (uv cache clean) will break all installed packages by way of removing the underlying source files. Use symlinks with caution.

Don't use it! Use a simple:

uv add copy flask requests

Maybe the error comes from the use of this flag!

Q: error[E0463]: can't find crate for `alloc` error from imported crate when building for thumbv8m.main-none-eabi A:

As @jthulhu and @chaim-friedman mentioned at the comment, I could solve this problem by adding build-std = ["core", "alloc"] in the file .cargo/config.toml, under the [unstable] section.

Q: Is there a way to inherit nested types? A:

Why the need to declare local type in each derived class? Aren't nested or internal types available to all derived classes? Well declaring them inside private or protected section may limit their availability to derived classes.

Any way I believe OP might have an error in declaration of TThreadAffinityFlags = set of TAttributeFlag;.

I assume TThreadAffinityFlags = set of TThreadAffinityFlag; is what might have been intended.

Q: Tour of Go exercise #18: Slices A:

Do I need to create a for loop in which I assign every element of my slice to a value in the range of dx?

Yes:

  • an outer loop to assign a[x] with a []uint8 slice of dx size,
  • with an inner loop 'y' for each element a[x] (which is a []uint8) in order to assign a[x][y] with the asked value (ie, one of the "interesting functions" like x^y, (x+y)/2, and x*y).
    x and y are indexes in a range over a slice (a, then a[x]): see "For statements".

I like (x ^ y) * (x ^ y):

As rwilson04 comments below:

x*x + y*y is another good one

Waqas Ilyas suggests in the comments: y * 10000 / (x + 1)

EdvardM suggests in the comments: (x+y)/2 * (x^y):

Chubby Cows proposes in the comments: ((x - y) * -1) * (x + y) / 2:

Matt Welke adds in the comments: 2*y ^ 2*3*x ^ 3

Q: Decide if the Qt close event is user or system-generated A:

One solution is to rely on an Exit button for closing the application. Then, a close event can be checked if event.spontaneous() is True, indicating a system quit, restart, or shutdown. And, in that case immediately closing the process with event.accept(). The logic you need is demonstrated in the following minimal application which will both confirm the close when the exit button is clicked and will immediately close in the case of a system restart, quit, or shutdown.

import sys
from PyQt6.QtCore import Qt
from PyQt6.QtWidgets import (
    QApplication,
    QWidget,
    QPushButton,
    QMessageBox,
    QVBoxLayout
)
from PyQt6.QtGui import QCloseEvent

class MainWindow(QWidget):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.setWindowTitle("Exit Confirmation Example")
        self.setMinimumWidth(350)
        self.exit_button: QPushButton = QPushButton("Exit")
        self.exit_button.setFixedWidth(100)
        layout = QVBoxLayout(self)
        layout.addWidget(self.exit_button, alignment=Qt.AlignmentFlag.AlignHCenter)
        self.exit_button.clicked.connect(self.request_exit)

        # _app_exit_requested is True when Exit button is clicked
        # _app_exit_requested is False when the system initiates the close
        self._app_exit_requested = False

    def request_exit(self):
        self._app_exit_requested = True
        self.close()

    def closeEvent(self, event: QCloseEvent):
        # check for a system initiated close and proceed with the close if so
        if event.spontaneous():  # macOS system quit / restart / shutdown
            print("System initiated close")
            event.accept() # close proceeds
            return

        if self._app_exit_requested:
            print("Exit button clicked")
            reply = QMessageBox.question(
                self,
                "Confirm Exit",
                "Are you sure you want to exit?",
                QMessageBox.StandardButton.Yes | QMessageBox.StandardButton.No,
                QMessageBox.StandardButton.No
            )

            if reply == QMessageBox.StandardButton.Yes:
                event.accept() # close proceeds
            else:
                self._app_exit_requested = False
                event.ignore() # close is canceled
        else:
            event.accept() # close proceeds
            return

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app = QApplication(sys.argv)
    window = MainWindow()
    window.show()
    sys.exit(app.exec())

Q: Why we need a master branch in Git-flow? A:

Just a note about "Why would I need a whole branch with history?". This is a strange statement, implying that this somehow has a cost. It doesn't. The history is in the commits, branches and tags are just decoration. Your repo without a master branch but with tags instead would be the same history, with different labels here and there.
